statement.tex: %text Solve the following differential equation \[ \qquad (x^2-y^2)\cdot dx +2xy\cdot dy = 0 \] given that $y=1$ when $x=1$ %

options.tex:
%text The given equation \[\quad (x^2-y^2)\cdot dx +2xy\cdot dy = 0\]
is of the form
\[ \frac{dy}{dx} + Px = Q \implies\text{ first-order linear equation}\] %

reason.tex:
%text Just a little algebra is required here.
% \begin{align} (x^2-y^2)\cdot dx &+2xy\cdot dy = 0 \\ \therefore 2xy\frac{dy}{dx} &= (y^2-x^2) \\ \implies \frac{dy}{dx} &= \underbrace{\dfrac{\left[\left( \frac{y}{x}\right)^2 - 1\right]\cdot x^2}{2\frac{y}{x}\cdot x^2}} _{\text{Factor out $x^2$}} \\ \implies \frac{dy}{dx} &= \underbrace{\dfrac{\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)^2 - 1}{2\frac{y}{x}}}_{F\left( \frac{y}{x}\right)} \end{align} %text
As we can see, \[ \frac{dy}{dx} = F\left( \frac{y}{x}\right) \]. This is what \underline\text{homogenous} differential equations look like. %

options.tex:
%text Let \[ y = v\cdot x \implies \frac{dy}{dx} = v + x\frac{dv}{dx} \]
%

reason.tex:
%text We know that it is a homogenous differential equation.
The first step is therefore to let \[ \qquad y = v\cdot x \]
And hence \[ \qquad \frac{dy}{dx} = v + x\frac{dv}{dx} \] %

options.tex: %text With \[ y = v\cdot x \] % \begin{align} F\left( \frac{y}{x} \right) =F(v) &= \frac{v^2-1}{2v} \\ \therefore v + x\frac{dv}{dx} &= \frac{v^2 - 1}{2v} \\ \implies \int\frac{2v}{1+v^2}\cdot dv &= -\int\frac{dx}{x} \\ \end{align}

%text With \[ y = v\cdot x \] % \begin{align} F\left( \frac{y}{x} \right) =F(v) &= \frac{v^2-1}{2v} \\ \therefore v + x\frac{dv}{dx} &= \frac{v^2 - 1}{2v} \\ \implies \int\frac{2v}{1+v^2}\cdot dv &= \int \frac{dx}{x} \\ \end{align}
